TopicTitle: How do I put the fairings on?

Articles.Content: Sounds stupid, but I can't read the options that come up as I begin to drag the fairing up and over the things I'm trying to cover up. I can't see how to lock it off, or complete it. What are those three lines of text on the screen telling me?

IIRC the top line says something like "[LMB] Place segment". Middle line "[RMB] remove segment". Bottom line I can't remember for sure, might be [ESC] to cancel. 

Basically press the left mouse button to build a section of the fairing, but the top line of text must be green. If it's not it won't let you build it. Keep going as desired, then to close it just bring it to the center, and the top line of text will change to (I think) blue and say "close fairing". 

You can also close on part of the rocket to make an interstage fairing, but getting it to work right can be a little tricky. 

As always, if you're having a specific problem, pictures of your rocket in the VAB while you're trying to build your fairings will help.
That should do it, I think. Thanks.

45 minutes ago, JackBush said:

Sounds stupid, but I can't read the options that come up as I begin to drag the fairing up and over the things I'm trying to cover up. I can't see how to lock it off, or complete it. What are those three lines of text on the screen telling me?

While building a fairing, status text will show its mass and cost, and tell whether the next section will close the fairing. The text will be green if the current section is valid, and orange if it can't be created.  I think when closing a fairing the colour is a kind of light blue.  the text is really very hard to see and would be good to see something different in terms of it's implementation.

So basically:

Right click on fairing base
Select Build Fairing
Drag fairing to first point and left click to lock it off (if it doesn't lock off it's for a reason - try a slightly different point and try again)
Repeat until you have the shape you want
To close the fairing bring the fairing inwards until the text changes to some kind of bluey green colour

 

Hope that helps.  If you are still stuck I think there's a few tutorials on youtube and almost certainly on this forum.  I can't link to them right now as at work.

Thanks

When you first attach the fairing base plate below the payload, it automatically goes into "build fairing" mode with the procedural fairing stuck to your cursor.  The basic procedure from then on is, move the mouse out and/or up from the baseplate while watching the color of the text that appears as you're building the fairing.  If the text is green, left-click to fix that part of the fairing in place and continue building the next section.  To complete the fairing (assuming this is a nose cone), eventually bring the sides in above the payload.  They won't quite meet but if the text is green, when you left-click it will close off the fairing in a point.  If this is an interstage fairing, bring it up and in to the sides of the part above and left-click when you see green text.  That will also close the fairing.

If you right-click at any point in this process, you exit "build" mode and have to start over.  To start over, right-click on the base plate and select "build fairing".  You can delete completed fairings by right-clicking the base plate and selecting "delete fairing".

Some tips and tricks.....

If you don't want to build the fairing immediately after you attach the base plate, just right-click to exit build mode and go about your business.  When you later want to do the fairing, right-click on the base plate and select "build fairing".

Because right-clicking kills the build process, you need to position the camera where you need it ahead of time, so you don't need to move it while building the fairing.  Either that or use the arrow and KP-/KP+ keys to move the camera instead of right-click and drag.

If the base plate is the same diameter or smaller than the parts above, the 1st section of the fairing is called the "base section".  This must come out mostly horizontally at least far enough to be slightly wider than the widest thing above it.  This includes parts that stick out the sides of the parts stacked directly above the base plate.  If you base plate is small compared to the width of the payload, you might have to make 2 base sections.

Once you have the width of the fairing established, you can go straight up making cylinders.  You can only go so for at a time (IOW, fairing sections have a maximum size).  Each time you go as far as you can, left-click to lock that part in place and start with the next section.  Once you get near or just beyond the widest part of the load, you can start bringing the fairing in towards a point.  It's possible to do this from below the widest part of the payload, but then you'll have bits of payload clipping through the fairing, which is a bad thing.

If your base plate is larger than the widest part of the payload, you can go straight up from the beginning.  Also, you can run struts from the payload down to the top surface of the base plate inside the fairing, which is sometimes necessary to stabilize the payload during launch.

When building fairings, don't make them as small as you can.  Give some elbow room inside them.  This helps prevent parts of the fairing from hitting parts of the payload (they especially like to destroy solar panels).

When you complete a fairing, it will appear in the staging list along with your decouplers and rocket engines.  Be sure to drag the fairing where it needs to be on the list.  I recommend putting it at the very top so it won't fire when you stage anything.  Then, once you want to open it, you can right-click on the base plate and select "deploy" to fire the fairing.

Do not deploy fairings while the ship is under thrust or rotating.  This almost always causes parts of the fairing to hit the payload and/or other parts of the rocket.
